61.72.text: Felicia Browne was born in London in 1904,

64.60.text: in a relatively prosperous middle class family.

67.42.text: She went to the Slade School to study art in the 1920s

71.56.text: but probably the main turning point in her life was in 1928

75.46.text: when she went to study sculpture in Berlin because it coincided with the rise of Nazism

81.68.text: and she was drawn into the anti-fascist politics of that time.

87.00.text: When Felicia Browne returned from Berlin she joined the communist party

91.14.text: and she came under surveillance from MI5

93.56.text: who then monitored her career until her departure for Spain in 1936.

100.70.text: Over 2500 British men and women went to fight in the international brigades

106.60.text: or serve in medical services in the Spanish Civil War.

111.64.text: I think it’s a British history in a way that, really, could be more acknowledged,

116.66.text: British people, probably, need to know a lot more about the altruism that they showed at that particular period

123.28.text: towards people who were really suffering and in trouble.

126.80.text: I think it’s a proud moment.

132.40.text: Shortly after her arrival in Barcelona,

134.48.text: the military rebellion against the elected government of the Spanish Republic took place and

140.24.text: on the streets of Barcelona there was street fighting between the rebel soldiers and workers militias

149.90.text: So, in early August she was finally able to join the militia

154.00.text: and the last recorded words that we have are her saying to a British journalist, on the steps of the barracks,

160.26.text: I’m a member of the London communist party and I can fight as well as any man.

165.90.text: The next we hear of her is on 22 August when,

169.06.text: by this stage, her militia group had gone to fight on the Aragon front.

173.82.text: They then took part in a raid,

176.18.text: one of the Italian volunteers was wounded

179.80.text: and Felicia Browne went to his assistance

182.28.text: and in the process she was shot dead.

186.30.text: After her death, her sketches that she had been drawing of the Republican militia

191.74.text: were retrieved and were sent back to London

195.18.text: and there they were put on sale as part of an exhibition to raise funds for Spanish medical aid.

202.88.text: Felicia Browne was probably the first British person to die in the Spanish Civil War

207.82.text: and certainly the only British woman to play a combatant role.

216.44.text: My father was a Republican journalist and he was part of the move out of Spain when the Second Republic fell in 1939,

226.14.text: this is a story that we simply didn’t know, such a huge event in his life

231.08.text: and which meant that he was exiled to this country.

235.50.text: I've explored this conflict and period of history through my work,

283.36.text: I might also take an object like a suitcase and
